top_comment.text:
Great! Just the recipe I was looking for. I do not have a mixer like yours 
so getting the butter mix with sugar and eggs is a little hard. What if I 
melt the butter and add it like that? Would it still work?﻿
top_comment.author: Nehir Banaz

comments.text:
If your butter is at room temperature, it makes it a little easier! I like 
to keep my butter out for about an hour and a half before I use it.
comments.author: Blair Fowler

comments.text:
I don't have one too and I always make cookies. I let the butter out of the 
fridge for about 2 hours (or you can microwave it for a few seconds, just 
don't let it melt), and then I use a spatula to cream the butter with the 
sugar and the whisk to combine the eggs, then back to the spatula to 
combine the dry ingredients!! Doing it by hand is the best in my opinion, I 
feel like I actually did it, if you know what I mean. Hope this helped. x
comments.author: Rana Ch

comments.text: you could use a hand whisk, back of a spoon or an electric whisk
comments.author: Jean Lagman

comments.text:
Don't melt the butter.. Let it soften in your microwave for 5-10 second 
intervals until the butter gives in when you press it with your finger. 
Don't let it go too far with the melting process or the cookies won't come 
out right.. Hope this helps!
comments.author: Kailynn Wilcox

comments.text:
No you can not melt the butter. It will make the dough runny. It's pretty 
easy to do by hand just make sure your butter is soft keep your butter out 
for a few hours before using.
comments.author: Amanda Krystyna

top_comment.text:
I have a little question. The recipe makes about a dozen of cookies, if I 
want to double the recipe, I need to double the ingredients, right? What 
about eggs? Do I need to put 4 eggs instead of 2 or the number of them 
stays the same? :)﻿
top_comment.author: Kate Bebe

comments.text: Thanks a lot!
comments.author: Kate Bebe

comments.text: Nah just add three ull be right
comments.author: Mikzii

comments.text:
Yes, if you are doubling the recipe you need to double the eggs too, 
otherwise the consistency will not be the same.

comments.text:
@taythunderbolt It's really nice. The cookie is crispy on the outside and 
very chewy inside. But it's pretty sweet so don't eat too much as it would 
get sickening after some time. I personally think that the espresso powder 
is pretty essential cos the cookies can get pretty sweet so the espresso 
powder can offset it a little. But I don't use espresso powder, I just use 
any coffee powder I can find to replace it. Without it, the cookies is 
overwhelmingly sweet.

top_comment.text:
these are soooo good, but the dough was extremely sticky!  i had to spray 
my hands with cooking spray, and even then, the dough stuck to my hands and 
fingers as i was trying to roll the balls.... and it was very cold dough! 
you didn't show the whole process of rolling the balls, so did you have the 
same problem?  (i don't have a cookie scoop, had to use a tablespoon - to 
which the dough stuck and wouldn't come out except in sticky globs.)﻿
top_comment.author: Kali Dallas

comments.text:
+kiara smyth This is pretty much a basic chocolate doughnut hole recipe. I 
tried this version and deep fried it and made some mighty fine doughnut 
holes, I did add more flour about 1/2 cup to start. 
P.S. I don't think she ever responds to these comments probably never reads 
many of them either. Hope this helps.
comments.author: Mountain MawMaw

comments.text: I left mine in overnight and they were still really sticky.
comments.author: kiara “beforehecheats21” smyth

comments.text:
+Anju Takuma
 yes, i left it over night!
comments.author: Kali Dallas

comments.text: Are you sure you kept it in the fridge for long enough?
comments.author: Anju Takuma

comments.text:
that's what i was using - a tablespoon measure and a regular spoon, and 
everything just was so sticky.
i've been looking at several other similar recipes, and i think next time, 
i'm going to add about 2 tblsp more flour to the batter.  (many people 
measure flour differently - i use a scoop to put mine into the measuring 
cup then level off, but maybe laura scoops hers with the cup until it looks 
level - so maybe her "cup of flour" and mine are off by about that much.)  
that could definitely make a difference in how sticky the batter is without 
making a difference in the taste.
comments.author: Kali Dallas

comments.text:
oh hmm. I didn't have much of that kind of problem when I was using my 
tablespoon measurement. I used one spoon and one tablespoon measurement to 
scoop out my dough. the spoon helped the cookie dough easily come out of 
the tablespoon measurement so I didn't really have a problem with it .(:
comments.author: polymerclaylova

comments.text:
+polymerclaylova
actually, that's what i ended up doing.  but even trying to get the dough 
out of the scoop was a mess, so my hands, the bowl which held the dough, my 
counter and my spoon were all a sticky gooey mess before i was finished.
the cookies are delicious, though, so i probably will try this recipe 
again. 
maybe dumping the dough onto waxed paper then freezing it, then trying to 
cut it instead of scooping might work?
comments.author: Kali Dallas

comments.text:
One tip I found while making this is that I first scooped out 1 tbsp of the 
cookie dough into my powdered sugar. I coated the cookie dough with 
powdered sugar before rolling it into a ball. This somewhat helped my 
problem with the sticky dough. Hope it helps (:
comments.author: polymerclaylova

comments.text:
I just posted a comment with the same problem and then I saw this! I don't 
understand why it was so sticky! It took me so long to get them in he oven!!

captions.text:
Hi guys I'm Laura Vitale and on this episode
of Laura in the Kitchen I'm going want share

with you my chocolate crinkles. There chocolate
crinkle cookies, I just call them my chocolate

crinkles. They're really really good, they've
got a great texture there so adorable and

I'm thrilled to share the recipe with you.
Let me take you over the ingredients so we

can get started. You'll need all purpose flour,
some cocoa powder, instant espresso powder,

salt, and baking powder. Granulated sugar,
eggs, unsalted butter that's been softened

at room temperature, vanilla extract, and
you'll also need some confectioner's sugar

or powdered sugar, but that'll come a little
bit later. So lets get started. I've got my

big standing mixture fitted with a paddle
attachment and in here I'm going to add in

my butter that's been softened and I'm going
to cream that together with my sugar. Get

those to combine, it won't be perfectly creamy
but that's okay. In the mean time I'm going

to mix together my dry ingredients and if
you don't want to add instant espresso powder

you don't have to I personally think that
a little bit of coffee into chocolate is not

enough to make it taste like mocha and coffee-like
I just put enough to make the chocolate taste

really chocolaty and deliciousness. If you
don't want to add it you don't have to, but

it does make a difference. So that's looking
good I'm not going to be to worried about

cause its not going to be supper creamy so
to that I'm going to add in my eggs and a

splash of vanilla and then wait for it all
to get nice and combined. That looks good

enough. Alright lets get the dry ingredients
in here. Did I get all spill that all over

the place, no, I managed to not hardly spill
anything at all. Whoa but I did manage to

get a cocoa facial. Okay all I'm going to
do is mix together I'm until it is nicely

combined and that's it. Now this does have
to go in the fridge, the dough has to go in

the fridge has to cool and set for a minimum
of about three hours. I'm probably going leave

mine it in there for about three or four hours
depending on how much time I have. You can

do this up to overnight and which will be
great, but a minimum of three hours should

do it. So I'm just going for this to get all
incorporated and then we'll get out of here

and into the fridge. Oakie doke lets get all
out of there. Bit of a tricky situation. And

now all I'm going do is wrap this in some
plastic wrap and pop it into the fridge for

several hours and then we'll get going on
forming them and popping them in the oven.

My cookie dough was in the fridge for about
four hours now I have my oven preheated to

350F I've got as baking sheet lined with parchment
paper and I also have some confectioner's

sugar here. I'm going form mine with my little
ice cream scoop. Take your dough, it may be

a little tricky at first but there you go,
and than I just roll it with my hands, dip

it into your confectioner sugar, and place
them a couple of inches apart on your baking

sheet. My cookies are going to go into the
oven for about 10-12 minutes or until they're

all crackly looking. Let them cool and than
I'm going show you what they look like when

their done. My cookies were in the oven for
exactly 12 minutes and I have let them cool

for about 20 minutes now so they are ready
for me to dig in. And you can see they are

absolutely beautiful so so perfect for any
occasion I'm going go right in to this one

over here. Look at the interior. It's almost
like a mix between a cookie and a brownie,

let's call it a "bookie" a brownie cookie
a "bookie". They are undeniably one of the

best cookies you'll ever eat. I promise. They're
not really thin and crispy cookie, there chewy

and soft, flavorful, chocolaty I don't think
you could want anymore. Mmm - look at that.

I've been 
chewing for the past six years here. LauraintheKitchen.com
will have the recipe for you. I hope you have

enjoyed spending time with me, and I hope
that you are happy now that you've got your

chocolate crinkle cookie recipe that you have
all been requesting for so so long. Hope that

you've enjoyed spending time with me and I'll
see you next time. Good bye.

So we can get started [snort]. I rock to the
beat of my own snap. Ready?

title: Chocolate Crinkle Cookie Recipe - Laura Vitale - Laura in the Kitchen Episode 756
